trans-unit.source: In this step, you manually create the availability group listener in Failover Cluster Manager and SQL Server Management Studio (SSMS).
trans-unit.target: In this step, you manually create the availability group listener in Failover Cluster Manager and SQL Server Management Studio (SSMS).

trans-unit.source: Open Failover Cluster Manager from the node hosting the primary replica.
trans-unit.target: Open Failover Cluster Manager from the node hosting the primary replica.

trans-unit.source: Select the Networks node, and note the cluster network name.
trans-unit.target: Select the Networks node, and note the cluster network name.

trans-unit.source: This name will be used in the $ClusterNetworkName variable in the PowerShell script.
trans-unit.target: This name will be used in the $ClusterNetworkName variable in the PowerShell script.

trans-unit.source: Expand the cluster name, and then click Roles.
trans-unit.target: Expand the cluster name, and then click Roles.

trans-unit.source: In the Roles pane, right-click the availability group name and then select Add Resource > Client Access Point.
trans-unit.target: In the Roles pane, right-click the availability group name and then select Add Resource > Client Access Point.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Add Client Access Point for Availability Group</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Add Client Access Point for Availability Group</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the Name box, create a name for this new listener, then click Next twice, and then click Finish.
trans-unit.target: In the Name box, create a name for this new listener, then click Next twice, and then click Finish.

trans-unit.source: Do not bring the listener or resource online at this point.
trans-unit.target: Do not bring the listener or resource online at this point.

trans-unit.source: Click the Resources tab, then expand the Client Access Point you just created.
trans-unit.target: Click the Resources tab, then expand the Client Access Point you just created.

trans-unit.source: You will see the IP Address resource for each of the cluster networks in your cluster.
trans-unit.target: You will see the IP Address resource for each of the cluster networks in your cluster.

trans-unit.source: If this is an Azure-only solution, you will only see one IP address resource.
trans-unit.target: If this is an Azure-only solution, you will only see one IP address resource.

trans-unit.source: If you are configuring a hybrid solution, continue with this step.
trans-unit.target: If you are configuring a hybrid solution, continue with this step.

trans-unit.source: If you are configuring an Azure only solution, skip to the next step.
trans-unit.target: If you are configuring an Azure only solution, skip to the next step.

trans-unit.source: Right-click the IP Address resource that corresponds to your on-premises subnet, then select Properties.
trans-unit.target: Right-click the IP Address resource that corresponds to your on-premises subnet, then select Properties.

trans-unit.source: Note the IP Address Name and network name.
trans-unit.target: Note the IP Address Name and network name.

trans-unit.source: Select Static IP Address, assign an unused IP address and then click OK.
trans-unit.target: Select Static IP Address, assign an unused IP address and then click OK.

trans-unit.source: Right-click the IP Address resource that corresponds to your Azure subnet and then select Properties.
trans-unit.target: Right-click the IP Address resource that corresponds to your Azure subnet and then select Properties.

trans-unit.source: If the listener later fails to come online due to a conflicting IP address selected by DHCP, you can configure a valid static IP Address in this properties window.
trans-unit.target: If the listener later fails to come online due to a conflicting IP address selected by DHCP, you can configure a valid static IP Address in this properties window.

trans-unit.source: In the same IP Address properties window, change the IP Address Name.
trans-unit.target: In the same IP Address properties window, change the IP Address Name.

trans-unit.source: This IP address name will be used in the $IPResourceName variable of the PowerShell script.
trans-unit.target: This IP address name will be used in the $IPResourceName variable of the PowerShell script.

trans-unit.source: Repeat this step for each IP resource if your solution spans multiple Azure VNets.
trans-unit.target: Repeat this step for each IP resource if your solution spans multiple Azure VNets.
